Award.AwardTitle: NIPS 2015 Workshop on Machine Learning For Healthcare

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The rise in availability and size of clinical data presents rich opportunities to develop and apply machine learning methods to solve problems faced by clinicians and usher in new forms of medical practice (such as personalized medicine) that would otherwise be infeasible. This workshop, focused on machine learning for healthcare, will be co-located with the annual Neural Information Processing Systems (NIPS) conference in Montreal, the foremost international meeting for machine learning research. The workshop will i) help build the community of machine learning researchers focused on solutions to healthcare problems, and ii) foster discussions between machine learning and clinical researchers to leverage machine learning in service of healthcare. The workshop includes industry and academic participants. It includes a "healthcare challenges" session in which clinical researchers will bring new problems to the statistical machine learning community.

This award supports Ph.D student attendance at the workshop, and hence will influence the future workforce in applications of statistical learning to healthcare. The students will be introduced to key open questions and interact with established machine learning and clinical researchers, thus encouraging their investment into this emerging domain.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent years have seen an unprecedented rise in the availability and size of collections of clinical data such as electronic health records. These rich data sources present opportunities to apply and develop machine learning methods to solve problems faced by clinicians and to usher in new forms of medical practice that would otherwise be infeasible. 


We proposed to organize a workshop focused on machine learning for healthcare at this year’s annual Neural Information Processing Systems (NIPS) conference in Montreal, Canada, the foremost international meeting for machine learning research. The goal of the workshop was to 1) continue to build the community of machine learning researchers who are focused on developing computational solutions for pressing healthcare problems, and 2) foster discussions between machine learning researchers and clinicians of how machine learning can be used to address fundamental problems in healthcare.


NSF funding was used to partially support 11 students to travel to the NIPS 2015 workshop on Machine Learning for Health Care, held in Montreal. The workshop was a huge success. It was one of the most highly attended workshops at NIPS (well over 200 attendees) and had talks on topics including AI in Emergency Care, phenotyping of autism disorders, using machine learning for mental health care, the importance of interpretability of models, personalized mobile health interventions, and detecting birth asphyxia in babies. The workshop provided networking opportunities that led to several new collaborations. In total, the workshop received 79 paper and 18 healthcare pitch submissions (a new idea introduced this year), demonstrating unprecedented interest in the field. The final schedule for the workshop and recorded videos of the presentations are available online at: https://sites.google.com/site/nipsmlhc15/
